question: Match the following male reproductive system terms with their NCERT-based descriptions:
column_II: Testes, accessory ducts, glands and external genitalia
matches: Location of male reproductive system–Pelvis region
Components of male reproductive system–Testes, accessory ducts, glands and external genitalia
Position of testes–Outside the abdominal cavity
Pouch enclosing the testes–Scrotum

question: Match the following testis-related terms with their NCERT-based descriptions:
column_I: Shape of each testis in adults
column_II: Helps in maintaining low temperature of testes
matches: Function of scrotum–Helps in maintaining low temperature of testes
Required temperature for spermatogenesis–2–2.5°C lower than normal body temperature
Shape of each testis in adults–Oval
Length of testis–About 4 to 5 cm

question: Match the following testis structure terms with NCERT-based descriptions:
column_I: Number of compartments in each testis
matches: Width of testis–About 2 to 3 cm
Covering of testis–Dense covering
Number of compartments in each testis–About 250
Name of compartments in testis–Testicular lobules

question: Match the following seminiferous tubule terms with NCERT-based descriptions:
column_II: Male germ cells and Sertoli cells
Undergo meiotic divisions to form sperms
matches: Contents of each testicular lobule–One to three seminiferous tubules
Site of sperm production–Seminiferous tubules
Lining cells of seminiferous tubules–Male germ cells and Sertoli cells
Function of male germ cells–Undergo meiotic divisions to form sperms

question: Match the following interstitial cell terms with NCERT-based descriptions:
column_II: Leydig cells and small blood vessels
matches: Function of Sertoli cells–Provide nutrition to germ cells
Region outside seminiferous tubules–Interstitial spaces
Cells found in interstitial spaces–Leydig cells and small blood vessels
Function of Leydig cells–Synthesize and secrete androgens

question: Match the following Leydig cell and accessory terms with NCERT-based descriptions:
matches: Hormones secreted by Leydig cells–Androgens
Other cells in interstitial space–Immunologically competent cells
Function of androgens–Testicular hormones
Figure showing seminiferous tubule structure–Figure 2.2

question: Match the following male accessory duct terms with NCERT-based descriptions:
column_I: Connection between seminiferous tubules and vasa efferentia
column_II: Rete testis, vasa efferentia, epididymis, vas deferens
matches: Sex accessory ducts–Rete testis, vasa efferentia, epididymis, vas deferens
Connection between seminiferous tubules and vasa efferentia–Rete testis
Ducts that leave the testis–Vasa efferentia
Location of epididymis–Posterior surface of each testis

question: Match the following vas deferens terms with NCERT-based descriptions:
column_I: Vas deferens receives a duct from
matches: Epididymis leads to–Vasa efferentia
Vas deferens ascends to–Abdomen
Vas deferens loops over–Urinary bladder
Vas deferens receives a duct from–Seminal vesicle

question: Match the following urethra terms with NCERT-based descriptions:
matches: Ejaculatory duct opens into–Urethra
Function of accessory ducts–Store and transport sperms
Urethra originates from–Urinary bladder
Urethra extends through–Penis

question: Match the following external male genital terms with NCERT-based descriptions:
column_I: Figure showing ducts and urinary bladder
matches: External opening of urethra–Urethral meatus
Urethra passes through–Penis
Duct opening into urethra–Ejaculatory duct
Figure showing ducts and urinary bladder–Figure 2.1a
